matched.expectedTitle: Server-Side Request Forgery in URL Converter
matched.actualTitle: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via URL Parameter
matched.matchReason: The expected SSRF vulnerability allowing bypass of localhost restriction is directly matched by the actual finding. The /convert endpoint's url parameter allows Server-Side Request Forgery, and the POC confirms access to localhost restricted endpoints (/admin/flag), exactly matching the expected impact of 'Bypass of localhost restriction' and 'Unauthorized access to admin interface'. The semantic match is clear: both describe SSRF in URL converter allowing arbitrary URL fetching without validation, enabling access to restricted admin endpoints.

matched.expectedTitle: Server-Side Request Forgery in URL Converter
matched.actualTitle: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) - file:// Protocol Allows Arbitrary File Read
matched.matchReason: This is a variant/extension of the core SSRF vulnerability. While the expected finding focuses on localhost restriction bypass, the actual finding demonstrates the same underlying SSRF vulnerability in the /convert endpoint. The file:// protocol attack exploits the same lack of URL validation, confirming the root cause: application passes user-supplied URL parameter directly to urllib.request.urlopen() without any validation.

matched.expectedTitle: Server-Side Request Forgery in URL Converter
matched.actualTitle: Environment Variable Disclosure via SSRF - Process Environment Access
matched.matchReason: Another variant of the core SSRF vulnerability. This finding demonstrates the same root cause (unvalidated URL parameter) but extends the attack to access /proc/self/environ. This is an escalation of the expected SSRF vulnerability, showing multiple attack vectors (localhost bypass, file read, environment variable disclosure) all stemming from the same unvalidated url parameter in /convert endpoint.

matched.expectedTitle: Server-Side Request Forgery in URL Converter
matched.actualTitle: SSRF with URL Encoding Bypass - Encoded file:// Protocol Bypass
matched.matchReason: This finding demonstrates an advanced bypass technique of the same core SSRF vulnerability. It shows that the application's URL parameter handling has no protocol validation even with URL-encoded inputs, confirming the fundamental SSRF vulnerability mentioned in expected findings exists and is exploitable through multiple encoding variations.

matched.expectedTitle: Server-Side Request Forgery in URL Converter
matched.actualTitle: SSRF with data:// URI Protocol Allows Arbitrary Content Injection
matched.matchReason: Another variant of the core SSRF vulnerability demonstrating that the /convert endpoint's url parameter accepts and processes arbitrary protocol handlers without validation. This confirms the same vulnerability can be exploited via data:// protocol for content injection, proving the complete absence of URL protocol validation.

extra.title: Complete Authentication Bypass - Unauthenticated Admin Access
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a critical vulnerability not mentioned in expected findings. Admin endpoints are completely accessible without any authentication mechanism. This is a separate vulnerability from SSRF, indicating missing authentication controls on admin panel.

extra.title: Missing Authentication and Authorization Controls on Admin Flag Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - Critical authorization vulnerability. While the expected findings mention SSRF allowing access to /admin/flag, this finding reveals the fundamental root cause: complete lack of authentication controls on the endpoint itself. This is an independent vulnerability enabling the SSRF attack to succeed in accessing sensitive data.

extra.title: Reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in markdown_text Parameter
extra.assessment: New discovery - High severity XSS vulnerability in a different parameter (markdown_text) of the same /convert endpoint. Not mentioned in expected findings but confirmed through POC with multiple payload vectors (script tags, img onerror, svg onload).

extra.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) - Missing Token Validation on /convert Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - CSRF vulnerability on /convert endpoint due to missing CSRF token validation. Not mentioned in expected findings. This can be combined with XSS for more severe impact.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers - CSRF and Clickjacking Protection
extra.assessment: New discovery - Missing security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-XSS-Protection, CSP, X-Content-Type-Options) on admin panel responses. Not mentioned in expected findings. While CSRF and clickjacking protection is mentioned, this finding documents the specific missing headers.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Sensitive Server Details in HTTP Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - Server header exposes Werkzeug/3.1.3 Python/3.13.3 details. Low severity information disclosure enabling attacker reconnaissance. Not mentioned in expected findings.
